stories.title: Usage statistics of server-side programming languages for websites

stories.text:
This question is inspired by the recent discussion on the future of Jekyll (a static site generator) :

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=28514029

Some posters worry about the lack of recent updates to Jekyll. Other posters feel Jekyll is mature and feature complete.

How would you define a product as complete feature? Given the widespread expectation that a product needs updates to add new features, do you believe that a piece of software cannot be feature complete without risking the danger of being as stagnant or dead?
stories.title: Ask HN: Can a software product ever be 'feature complete'?
ExpressVPN bought for $1bn by Brit biz with an interesting history in ad-tech
Turing Oversold. It's not Turing's fault, though

OpenBSD's scp(1) now uses SFTP protocol by default
India, Singapore to link their payments systems for low-cost cross-border txns
Climate change: World now sees twice as many days over 50C
